text:
As insurers work to
control health care costs,

patients increasingly face
high co-pays and deductibles.

For the majority of working
Americans who live paycheck

to paycheck, out-of-pocket
costs come at a time
they can least afford it.

The average
hospitalization results
in a 20% reduction in earnings.

Now, in work study in the
hospital financial assistance

programs, we find that
qualifying for assistance

increases the likelihood a
patient receives follow up
care.

And these aren't just
discretionary visits,

we find financial assistance
increases the detection

and management of treatment
sensitive conditions
like diabetes and depression.

And these aren't just
low income patients.

We study patients with
insurance making 350%
of the federal poverty line.

That's nearly $100,000 a
year for a family of four.

So what does this mean for
health care managers, insurers,
and policy makers?

We know that deductibles and
co-pays help reduce health care

costs, but when patients
cut back on care,

even these middle
class patients,

they're not just
cutting back on waste,

but missing out on care
where we know that treatment
makes a difference.
